wordpressWpDailyReads.title: Daily Reads 5/31/2019
wordpressWpDailyReads.content:
Hi, everyone. This week was a short one, due to the holiday weekend. With the weekend already here, we find out that Dashlane raised $110M and hired new CMO. Developers, designers, and landlords face a unique set of challenges when addressing the workspaces of young workers. Trump announces new tariffs on Mexico in response to migrants. Alzheimer’s disease not only erodes memory, but it also turns out money management skills as well. And those who don’t know history are doomed to repeat it, so learn the 5 top lessons history can tell us.

 

MARKETS

Dashlane raises $110M, nets new CMO in password management push

Dashlane, the popular password management service, has closed a $110-million Series D funding round and hired a new chief marketing officer: Joy Howard, who is currently CMO at Lyft and will join Dashlane in August.

 

BUSINESS

Less Collaboration More Quiet Building For Gen Z, The Digital Natives Coming Soon To The Workforce

In the last two years, millennials have become the largest generation in the American workforce. Developers, designers and landlords have been falling over themselves to create workplaces that will keep millennials happy to give companies a competitive edge in the war for talent.

ECONOMY

Trump announces new Mexican tariffs in response to migrants

In a surprise announcement that could derail a major trade deal, President Donald Trump announced Thursday that he is slapping a 5% tariff on all Mexican imports, effective June 10, to pressure the country to do more to crack down on the surge of Central American migrants trying to cross the U.S. border.

 

RETIREMENT

Alzheimer’s Erodes Money Skills Earlier Than Previously Thought, Duke Study Says

Alzheimer’s disease is known to cause a deterioration in money management skills, but a new research report indicates that this symptom can strike disease sufferers earlier than was previously thought.

 

PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT

Five Lessons from History

The most important lessons from history are the takeaways that are so broad they can apply to other fields, other eras, and other people. That’s where lessons have leverage and are most likely to apply to your own life.
